title: After a dramatic week, is Trump any closer to his trade goals?
content: The president made a partial reversal this week - here's a look at where it leaves five of his key ambitions.

title: UK announces further £450m military support to Ukraine
content: The package includes funding for radar systems, anti-tank mines and hundreds of thousands of drones.

title: Police raid barbers and vape shops suspected of being fronts for crime gangs
content: The BBC follows raids on hundreds of High Street businesses suspected of money laundering.

title: New pill can slow progression of incurable breast cancer
content: Around 3,000 women a year with advanced cancer could benefit from capivasertib which can slow the disease.

title: Six dead after helicopter crashes in New York's Hudson River
content: Five of the individuals on board were a family of tourists from Spain and the sixth person was the pilot,  officials say.

title: Oldest Post Office scandal victim says new compensation offer 'not good enough'
content: Betty Brown's offer was increased from 30% to 60%, but still below what she claimed when her life was "destroyed" by scandal.

title: British man's tattoo wrongly linked to Venezuelan gang in US government document
content: A tattoo belonging to a man from Derbyshire has appeared in a US government document used to identify members of Tren de Aragua, a notorious Venezuelan gang, despite the man having no connection to the group.

title: Prince Harry in surprise visit to Ukraine to meet war victims
content: The Duke of Sussex visits an orthopaedic clinic in the western city of Lviv.

title: Watch: Pope seen without usual papal attire
content: Pope Francis visits St Peter's Basilica in the Vatican, still with an oxygen tube, as he continues to recover from ill health.

title: OpenAI sues Elon Musk claiming 'bad-faith tactics'
content: Claim follows Mr Musk's own lawsuit earlier this year against OpenAI's Sam Altman.

title: Tributes for teens killed in crash near Heathrow
content: The three teenagers have been named by police as 17-year-old Star Tomkins, 18-year-old Harley Woods and 17-year-old Jimmy Savory

content: There is an anxious wait to find out what comes next - and if a currency war will follow.

title: 'It's fastest finger first' - traders on their tumultuous week

title: What does Trump's tariff pause mean for global trade?

content: Some analysts say that if costs incurred by tariffs pass to consumers, US iPhone prices could rise by hundreds of dollars.

title: Retreat or negotiating strategy? Trump steps back from all-out trade war
content: The US is now making nice – or at least nicer - with nations that had faced their retaliatory trade fire, writes Anthony Zurcher.

content: The Big Garden Birdwatch survey recorded the lowest ever numbers of starlings this year.

title: What we know about the Hudson helicopter crash
content: Six people have been confirmed to have died following the crash near to the New Jersey side of the Hudson.

title: General strike hits transport in Argentina
content: President Javier Milei has made sweeping cuts to public services since he took office 16 months ago.

title: Israeli army fired more than 100 shots in Gaza medics' killing, audio suggests
content: The analysis shows Israeli troops fired 100 shots during the attack which killed 15 people.

title: Michelle Obama dismisses divorce rumours

title: Supreme Court Sides With Migrant Trump Administration Wrongly Deported

title: Pressuring Migrants to ‘Self-Deport,’ White House Moves to Cancel Social Security Numbers
writer: Alexandra Berzon, Hamed Aleaziz, Nicholas Nehamas, Ryan Mac and Tara Siegel Bernard
content: By placing migrants in Social Security’s “death master file,” the Trump administration is seeking to cut off their access to credit cards, bank accounts and other financial services.

content: As legal challenges to the Trump administration mount, the justices are facing a key test — a flood of “emergency applications” asking for immediate intervention.

title: Mahmoud Khalil’s Lawyers Will Seek Testimony From Marco Rubio
content: Lawyers for the detained Columbia graduate said that the lack of substantive charges against him requires more information from the secretary of state. They acknowledge they are likely to fail.

title: Trump’s Tariff Fight With China Poses New Threat to US Farmers
content: Soybean producers warn that farms could go under as the Trump administration hits China with new tariffs of 145 percent.

content: President Trump on Thursday cited the growing water debt that Mexico owes the United States under a treaty governing the use of the countries’ shared rivers.

content: An executive from Spain, his wife and three children died in the crash, along with the helicopter’s pilot, officials said.

title: Charter Company in Fatal Helicopter Crash Had Prior Mechanical Failures
content: At least twice before in the past 12 years, aircraft operated by the firm New York Helicopter Charter failed while in flight.

content: The Trump administration is discussing asking a judge to enforce any deal it reaches with the school, which the White House says has not done enough to address antisemitism.

title: Effort to Get Starlink in South Africa Collides With Tension Over Musk
content: A government official is preparing to ease Black ownership rules that Elon Musk claims are racist and prevent his satellite internet provider from operating in his native country.

content: A presidential decree instructing the Justice Department to scrutinize whether a former official broke the law crosses a new line.

content: Four or five firms could soon agree to deals that would be unveiled as a package, in an escalation of the president’s crackdown on an industry that has drawn his ire.

content: Made from seaweed, the traditional Japanese food kanten is rich in dietary fiber and has almost zero calories.

title: Too Much Information: Osaka Expo Website’s Excessive Personal Data Demands
content: Osaka Expo’s ticket sales website has come under fire in Japan for its excessive requirements to provide personal information.

title: Seated Image of Amida Buddha, Kōzōji, Miyagi
content: Next to the main image in the Amida Hall at the temple Kōzōji in Miyagi Prefecture stands another statue of roughly the same size and age. Although now badly damaged, the finely proportioned features of the sculpture convey a powerful message across the centuries.

title: No Need for Nissan? Hon Hai Buyout Not in the Cards
content: When Honda walked away from the idea of merging with Nissan to create a new Japanese automotive giant earlier this year, it left a wide-open field with plenty of room for observers to wonder about other potential purchasers for the beleaguered automaker. An analyst notes that Hon Hai, named as one potential suitor for Nissan, is not a likely buyer, as its corporate focus is elsewhere.

title: Forward-Thinking Hokkaidō Initiative Meeting Eldercare Needs with Global Talent
content: A pressing issue for Japan’s aging population is ensuring enough care workers to look after the elderly. The town of Higashikawa in Hokkaidō is exploring a solution by inviting foreign workers for training in professional eldercare. How does the initiative overcome the language barrier and physical demands of nursing care to yield benefits for both workers and employers?

title: LDP Receives Reduced ¥13.6 Billion in Political Party Grants in 2025
content: Electoral setbacks meant the Liberal Democratic Party will receive ¥2 billion less in political party grants in 2025 than in the previous year.

title: Success Often Elusive for Asian Students in Japan: Many Dreamers Defeated by Kanji, Culture, Costs
content: Each year thousands of Asians enter Japan as language students with the aim of building successful careers. But not all are prepared for the mental, physical, and financial struggles involved. The author interviewed students and teachers at a Tokyo Japanese-language school to shed light on the challenges they face.

title: Japan Accepts 190 Refugees in 2024
content: Japan accepted 190 people as refugees in 2024; the figure dropped by more than a third from the record high of 303 in 2023.

title: Trump Tariffs Set to Deal Heavy Blow to Trade Partner Japan
content: Some 20% of Japan’s exports in 2024 went to the United States, with around a third of the total connected to the auto industry.

title: The Dark Underside of the Host Bar Industry
content: “Host clubs” are staffed by men who seek to charm their female clients into spending heavily, boosting their own income and rankings at the clubs. The industry has a dark side, though, as an urban sociologist and observer of the club scene explains.

title: Two-Thirds of Japan’s Family Businesses with No Successor as Children Go Their Own Way
content: Many small businesses in Japan face the issue of finding a successor to continue running them, as children of the current owners often show no interest in taking over.

title: Japan Records Total Trade Deficit of ¥5.5 Trillion in 2024—¥8.6 Trillion Surplus with United States
content: Japan’s overall balance of trade for 2024 showed a deficit of almost ¥5.5 trillion, but it had a bilateral trade surplus of some ¥8.6 trillion with the United States.

title: Japanese Survey on Disaster Preparedness Reveals Concerns About Safety Checks and Misinformation
content: A Japanese survey on disaster preparedness found that two in three of the respondents had concerns about confirming the safety of others in case of disaster, while almost as many were worried about misinformation.

title: Fukushima Daiichi Workers Share Their Stories
content: Fourteen years after the March 11, 2011, earthquake and tsunami that triggered meltdowns at Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station, some 4,700 people are on hand at the facility each day, working to decommission the reactor units in a process that will take decades. We spoke with some of the people taking on this mammoth project.

title: Rethinking the Nankai Trough Threat: The Importance of Earthquake Resilience
content: In August last year the Japanese authorities issued an unprecedented earthquake warning to communities near the Nankai Trough south of Honshū and Shikoku. A book by a veteran seismologist urges people to prepare for disaster through “earthquake resilience” rather than worrying about an event that will strike on its own geologic time scale, not according to our shorter schedules.

title: Japan’s World Heritage Sites: Hiroshima A-Bomb Dome Best Known Among Japanese
content: The Hiroshima Genbaku (A-Bomb) Dome is the best known of Japan’s World Heritage sites among the country’s population.

title: Kiritake Kanjūrō: Breathing Life into Bunraku Puppets
content: Kiritake Kanjūrō was designated a living national treasure in 2021 for bringing puppets to life through his masterful embodiment of the traditional techniques of bunraku puppetry.

title: Money Moves: Changes Affecting People’s Lives in Japan from April 2025
content: Inflation means prices are continuing to rise in Japan, but the government has rolled out more support for working parents.

title: Osaka: Where Japanese Manga Began Its Meteoric Rise
content: Japan’s manga are popular around the world today, but there was a time when the most creative currents in the scene sprang not from the publishing industry center of Tokyo, but from Osaka. A look at how Japan’s western urban center informed and inspired the world of manga in the twentieth century.

title: New Scandal for Ishiba Means New Lows for His Ratings in March
content: The Japanese media’s public opinion surveys for March 2025 paint a brutal picture for Prime Minister Ishiba Shigeru, who saw his support plummet in all eight polls. A fresh scandal erupting on March 13, involving his distribution of gift coupons to 15 Diet members from his party, sent his disapproval ratings to their highest point since he took office in October last year.
